A New Paradigm for Hardware?

August 4th, 2004 · No Comments

It seems to me that over the last few years, we are starting to see more and more of a certain type of hardware: hardware based on open source which can be “embraced and extended” by knowledgable enthuastists.

It seems like the first mainstream example is the Tivo. Within a few weeks of its introduction, people were hacking it to add bigger hard drives, network support and other interesting capabilities. Since then, we have hardware like the Netpliance iOpener, the Linksys WRT54G, and now the latest: the Linksys NSLU2. Much of this is due to the growth of Linux and the GNU tools in embedded devices.

But the real business question is: is this “hackability” good for the company and the consumer? The answer seems to me to be an unabashed YES! The knowledgable consumer will flock to them because they offer the ability to customize the device (and who doesn’t love hacking hardware late into a Friday night?). The company gets a “cult” following of consumers who recommend the product based on its “bang for the buck” and they can sell a product that has a slew of features which they don’t need to document or support.

The only problem I see is that something which can be hacked in software might hurt upgrade sales. A consumer may not upgrade to v2 of a product if there is a “hack” which adds the same feature to v1. I think that is a minor issue - most companies already provide free firmware upgrades (i.e. software updates). I have a NSLU2 on the way and can’t wait to start hacking it!
